photo.description: This is a statue of Oliver Cromwell outside the Palace of Westminster. It is in front of Westminster Hall. It is a commemorative statue dating from 1899, by Hamo Thornycroft. The base is made of Portland stone. The statue of Cromwell is made of bronze. It is Grade II listed. statue of Oliver Cromwell - Heritage Gateway The Palace of Westminster is a Grade I listed building and is a World Heritage Site. Westminster Palace- World Heritage Site

photo.description: Westminster Hall, the oldest existing part of the Palace of Westminster, was built by William II in 1097, after moving hsi royal residence from the Tower of London. Most kings followed suit for 450 years, until Henry VII built St. James's Palace in 1530. Westminster Hall is the only part of the original Palace to survive the fire of 1834 and was incorporated into Sir Charles Barry's Perpendicur Gothic design of the new palace. The Hall is marked by Hamo Thornycroft's 1899 statue of Oliver Cromwell--it was here that he was sworn in as Lord Protector in 1643, and Marochetti's 1860 statue of Richard the Lionheart (pictured here)--seated on his horse, sword raised. The roof of the Hall was originally supported by pillars but, during the reign of King Richard II, it was replaced by a hammerbeam roof designed by Henry Yevele and Hugh Herland. Westminster Hall is one of the largest halls in Europe with an unsupported roof, measuring 21x73m (68x240'). Although originally designed as a banquet hall, it came to be used primarily for judicial purposes, housing three of the most important courts in the land--the Court of King's Bench, the Court of Common Pleas, and the Court of Chancery--until they moved to the Royal Courts of Justice in 1882. It was here that the impeachment trial of Charles I after the Civil War, and the treason trials of Anne Boleyna, William Wallace and Guy Fawkes were held. From the 12th to 19th centuries, coronation banquets were held here, the last belonging to King George IV (1821). Today Westminster Hall is used for lyings-in-state, usually reserved for the Sovereign and their consorts. The only non-royals to receive one in the 20th century were Frederick Sleigh Roberts, 1st Earl Roberts (1914) and Sir Winston Churchill (1965). The most recent was that of Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother in 2002.

photo.description: Westminster Hall, the oldest existing part of the Palace of Westminster, was built by William II in 1097, after moving hsi royal residence from the Tower of London. Most kings followed suit for 450 years, until Henry VII built St. James's Palace in 1530. Westminster Hall is the only part of the original Palace to survive the fire of 1834 and was incorporated into Sir Charles Barry's Perpendicur Gothic design of the new palace. The Hall is marked by Hamo Thornycroft's 1899 statue of Oliver Cromwell--it was here that he was sworn in as Lord Protector in 1643, and Marochetti's 1860 statue of Richard the Lionheart (pictured here)--seated on his horse, sword raised. The roof of the Hall was originally supported by pillars but, during the reign of King Richard II, it was replaced by a hammerbeam roof designed by Henry Yevele and Hugh Herland. Westminster Hall is one of the largest halls in Europe with an unsupported roof, measuring 21x73m (68x240'). Although originally designed as a banquet hall, it came to be used primarily for judicial purposes, housing three of the most important courts in the land--the Court of King's Bench, the Court of Common Pleas, and the Court of Chancery--until they moved to the Royal Courts of Justice in 1882. It was here that the impeachment trial of Charles I after the Civil War, and the treason trials of Anne Boleyna, William Wallace and Guy Fawkes were held. From the 12th to 19th centuries, coronation banquets were held here, the last belonging to King George IV (1821). Today Westminster Hall is used for lyings-in-state, usually reserved for the Sovereign and their consorts. The only non-royals to receive one in the 20th century were Frederick Sleigh Roberts, 1st Earl Roberts (1914) and Sir Winston Churchill (1965). The most recent was that of Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother in 2002. Over the middle of the Palace lies St. Stephen's Tower, also called the Central Tower. At 91m (300') it is the shortest of the three principal towers, and is the only one with a spire. The octagonally shaped tower stands immediately above the Central Lobby. Its function was originally as a high-level air intake.

photo.description: Westminster Hall, the oldest existing part of the Palace of Westminster, was built by William II in 1097, after moving hsi royal residence from the Tower of London. Most kings followed suit for 450 years, until Henry VII built St. James's Palace in 1530. Westminster Hall is the only part of the original Palace to survive the fire of 1834 and was incorporated into Sir Charles Barry's Perpendicur Gothic design of the new palace. The Hall is marked by Hamo Thornycroft's 1899 statue of Oliver Cromwell--it was here that he was sworn in as Lord Protector in 1643, and Marochetti's 1860 statue of Richard the Lionheart (pictured here)--seated on his horse, sword raised. The roof of the Hall was originally supported by pillars but, during the reign of King Richard II, it was replaced by a hammerbeam roof designed by Henry Yevele and Hugh Herland. Westminster Hall is one of the largest halls in Europe with an unsupported roof, measuring 21x73m (68x240'). Although originally designed as a banquet hall, it came to be used primarily for judicial purposes, housing three of the most important courts in the land--the Court of King's Bench, the Court of Common Pleas, and the Court of Chancery--until they moved to the Royal Courts of Justice in 1882. It was here that the impeachment trial of Charles I after the Civil War, and the treason trials of Anne Boleyna, William Wallace and Guy Fawkes were held. From the 12th to 19th centuries, coronation banquets were held here, the last belonging to King George IV (1821). Today Westminster Hall is used for lyings-in-state, usually reserved for the Sovereign and their consorts. The only non-royals to receive one in the 20th century were Frederick Sleigh Roberts, 1st Earl Roberts (1914) and Sir Winston Churchill (1965). The most recent was that of Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother in 2002. Over the middle of the Palace lies St. Stephen's Tower, also called the Central Tower. At 91m (300') it is the shortest of the three principal towers, and is the only one with a spire. The octagonally shaped tower stands immediately above the Central Lobby. Its function was originally as a high-level air intake. A small tower is positioned at the front of the Palace, between Westminster Hall and Old Palace Yard, and contains the main entrance to the House of Commons at its base, known as St. Stephen's entrance.

The most recent was that of Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother in 2002. Over the middle of the Palace lies St. Stephen's Tower, also called the Central Tower. photo.description: This is a statue of Oliver Cromwell outside the Palace of Westminster. It is in front of Westminster Hall. It is a commemorative statue dating from 1899, by Hamo Thornycroft. The base is made of Portland stone. The statue of Cromwell is made of bronze. It is Grade II listed. statue of Oliver Cromwell - Heritage Gateway The House of Commons is behind the Cromwell statue. Big Ben pops out above it. The Palace of Westminster is a Grade I listed building and a World Heritage Site. The Palace of Westminster is a Grade I listed building and is a World Heritage Site.

photo.description: Close-up of the Cromwell statue during the conservation work in summer 2008. There is a striking difference – before cleaning on the left, and afterwards on the right. Erecting scaffolding around the statue of Cromwell allowed conservators to have a good look at the sculpture close up. Details included that the bible Cromwell holds in his hand is titled 'Holy Bible 1641'. The sculpture is signed 'Hamo Thornycroft 1897' on its base and the paw of the lion is dated '1899'. On the back of the statue base is written 'Founded by J W Singer and Sons Frome & London'. The J W Singer foundry, which was established in 1848, also cast two of the lions and the fountain in Trafalgar Square and many other public sculptures. Read more on the conservation work. This image is subject to parliamentary copyright. www.parliament.uk/
photo.tags: parliament westminster london mps lords housesofparliament robingroom olivercromwell cromwell conservation ukparliament uk unitedkingdom houseofcommons houseoflords commons mp peers politics
photo.title: Cromwell statue conservation work

photo.description: The Cromwell Association holds an annual service of commemoration on 3 September, the anniversary of Oliver Cromwell's death. Parliament gives permission for the laying of a wreath at the foot of the statue that stands near St Stephen’s Entrance. Read more on the conservation work. This image is subject to parliamentary copyright. www.parliament.uk/
photo.tags: parliament westminster london cromwell housesofparliament cromwellconservation commons lords mps houseofcommons houseoflords ukparliament uk unitedkingdom mp peers politics
photo.title: Cromwell anniversary

photo.description: Monday 11 August 2008, the scaffold build begins on the statue of Oliver Cromwell within the parliamentary estate. Read more about the Cromwell statue conservation work. This image is subject to parliamentary copyright. www.parliament.uk/
